awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Modern Optics in the City of Light, A Collaborative REU Site in Paris
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site in Physics hosted at the University of Michigan.  This international REU site, Modern Optics in the City of Light, will bring eight undergraduates to Paris each summer to conduct research, collaboratively, with faculty at the University of Michigan's Center for Ultrafast Optical Sciences (CUOS) and several Parisian research institutions: the University of Paris-Sacley, Ecole Polytechnique, Ecole Nationale de Techniques Avancées (ENSTA), the Institut d'Optique Graduate School, Université Paris-Sud 11, and Ecole Normale Supérieure de Cachan. The students will be in research teams that include the student, a faculty member at UM and a faculty member in one of the Parisian institutions. The students will spend one week in Ann Arbor, followed by nine weeks in Paris. Each student will keep weekly on-line research diaries to aid in communication with each full group. A CUOS faculty member or research scientist will accompany the students to Paris and stay for one week to ensure that the students get a good start. The students will be housed in a local hotel in Ann Arbor and at the Cité Universitaire in Paris. 

The research that will be conducted will include both on-going collaborative projects between CUOS and the French institutions and new collaborative projects. The research in all projects will all involve the use of ultrafast lasers to discover very current, state-of-the art phenomena in a wide range of fields including  relativistic optics, plasma physics, materials spectroscopy, nano-machining, patterned biological cell templating, high power fiber lasers, plasma x-ray sources, dynamics of nano-magnetic materials, terahertz imaging, biomedical imaging with shaped pulses, and the fatigue life studies of materials , as well as other topics. This site is supported by the  Physics REU program and by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Dates of 2018-2023 for this project

Project outcomes

Intellectual Merit:

Students gain a deep understanding of what research is like at a World class laboratory, outside of the United States.

Broader Impacts:

Students are immersed in a diverse group to navigate a foreign culture.

Outcomes:

Thirty two students have had an opportunity to work in a world class research laboratory inFrance for 2 months during the past four years we ran the program. The vast majority (92%) ofthe students are either in graduate school or plan to attend graduate school soon. 50% of theparticipants were women, 50% of the students were underrepresented minorities, and 69% of thestudents attend undergraduate schools where research is not a primary focus of their programs.

Products:

Summaries, images, student interviews, and whiteboard videos are available at : http://java.engin.umich.edu/ParisREU

 impact on the development of human resources:

Everything in this program if focussed on having an impact on the careers of the excellentundergraduate students. Our impact is measured by the fraction that choose to go tograduate school in a STEM discipline or end up working in a STEM career. More than 90%of our participants do this or plan to do this. We also view the decision of those few studentswho choose to go into other field if they discover that research in a STEM discipline is NOTfor them as a positive impact.

impact on institutional resources that form infrastructure:

This project represents an excellent recruiting tool for all institutions involved in the REUprogram. The University of Michigan actively recruits these excellent students.

impact on society beyond science and technology:

Creating innovative researchers will always have a positive impact on society beyondscience and technology. One clear outcome of our program is the international culturalexperience that our students get by living in Paris and commuting to work for two months.They have encountered massive French strikes, fear of terrorism, a vastly more internationalresearch environment than exists in the US (one lab in Paris only spoke Italian!). Thesecultural experiences will help these students be far more understanding and knowledgable ofour role in a global community and economy.

Changes in approach and reasons for change:

We continually improve our program each year to address issues in France as well as ways toimprove the experience for our students. During the past 4 years we have addressed thefollowing issues:

1) Changes in French laws and administration. Contracts are now required to be signed by eachstudent, researcher, and representative of UM. Our program can not extend beyond 2 monthsin France without a new requirement that the actual French labs pay the students. We used toadminister the program through Ecole Polytechnique and ENSTA. Ecole Polytechnique hasgone through a massive administrative reorganization and now we run the program throughENSTA. A new, and quite excellent, process has been developed by our French colleagues toidentify projects for our students each year. In the last year the administration has shifted tothe newly formed University of Paris-Saclay that combined 14 French institutions, including ENS Cachon, U. Paris Sud(Orsay), l’Institute d’Optique, and many others. U. Paris-Saclayhas greatly improved the process for finding research mentors and welcoming the studentsupon arrival in Paris. This past year the administration moved back to Ecole Polytechniqueand is running smoother than ever. We are very happy to be back where it all started in 2009.

2) We have instituted a mentoring plan by sending an email before the program begins to thestudent and their research mentor in France. We ask both to write down what theirexpectations are and get to know each other before even arriving.

Actual or Anticipated problems or delays in actions or plans to resolve them:

We have not had any issues recently. In fact, the program has been running very efficiently onboth the US and the French side. It is possible that this has been helped by our key facultymember in France, Gérard Mourou, who has been encouraging us to keep the program intactever since we started 11 years ago, recently was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics. While thisis great, it is much harder to go out to dinner with him as he now has far more commitmentsoutside of Paris.

Changes that have significant impact on expenditures:

None
